description.narrative: The proposed project, Ebola Emergency Liquidity Facility (EELF) is IFCs immediate response to the ongoing Ebola outbreak in West Africa and is targeting Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, the countries severely affected to date. It seeks to provide immediate private sector-focused support to help alleviate the immediate trade and foreign currency denominated working capital needs in the countries. IFCs immediate intervention relies on the use of IFCs Financial Institutions Group (FIG) platforms to quickly help clients with working capital and contribute to maintaining trade flows, supporting employment, and restoring supplies of key goods and services. This intervention is the first stage of a more comprehensive, cross-sector (FIG, MAS, and Infra) combined IS-AS response. EELFs total size is up to US$75 million for IFCs own account and would comprise discrete funding lines to each eligible bank in the three targeted countries. The tenor of each facility is up to 12 months, with renewable options. EELF will initially target existing IFC portfolio clients in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone and will later be also made available to other banks operating in West Africa.

Immediate Trade and Working Capital Relief: Through increased access to finance, the Facility will contribute to maintaining trade flows for basic and essential goods across key economic sectors (manufacturing, agri, energy) in the three countries severely affected by the Ebola outbreak. Improved availability of credit to these sectors is expected to benefit basic-good producers and importers, among others along the value chain, and therefore alleviate economic impact, sustain employment and maintain livelihoods. Demonstration Effect in FCS/IDA Countries: The Facility is expected to send a positive signal to the international community about IFC''s commitment to these fragile economies and will encourage other foreign institutions to follow.
